Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's decision was reasonable in rejecting the applicant's refugee claim based on sexual orientation and HIV status
Application_Facts: Pre-screening for HIV was prevalent in Venezuela, impacting the applicant's ability to find work; applicant claimed fear of persecution due to sexual orientation and HIV status
Decision_Outcome: Board rejected the applicant's refugee claim citing available state protection and internal flight alternative
Court_Ruling: Federal Court found the Board's decision unreasonable
Claimant_Status: Applicant with HIV-positive status and non-conforming sexual orientation
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on sexual orientation and HIV status
Assessment_Factor: Existence of systemic discrimination, availability of state protection, internal flight alternative
Applicable_Legislation: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of a Board decision
Evidence_Used: Evidence of pre-screening for HIV in employment in Venezuela
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to membership in particular social group (sexual orientation and HIV status)
Evidence_Assessed: Prevalence of HIV pre-screening in employment sector in Venezuela
Governing_Rule: A Convention refugee must face persecution that cannot be mitigated by state protection or internal flight alternative
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider whether systemic discrimination against HIV-positive individuals constituted persecution
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; case referred back to the Board
Harm_Assessment: Inability to secure employment due to HIV status and risk of stigma/discrimination based on sexual orientation
Cause_Description: Applicant feared persecution in Venezuela due to being gay and HIV-positive
Evidence_Handling: Board did not adequately assess evidence regarding systemic discrimination
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Issues: Failure to consider relevant evidence on systemic HIV discrimination
Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient consideration of evidence linking HIV status to persecution
Decision_Rationale: The Boardâ€™s decision was unreasonable due to failure to assess whether systemic discrimination amounted to persecution
Evidentiary_Issues: Board overlooked key evidence on employment discrimination based on HIV status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court in reviewing administrative decision
